customer_addr:
1768 Sweet Home Road
Broken Bow, OK 74728

citations.narrative:
There was a general lack of readily identifiable attendants throughout the facility. Customers were able to move freely
through the facility, feeding and interacting with a variety of animals, without appropriate supervision. The facility does not
utilize public barriers, and relies on employee oversight to ensure proper interactions between visitors and animals. Lack
of oversight poses a risk both to the animals of the facility, and to visiting personnel as well. All park guests able to
engage in public contact with the animals must be properly supervised by readily identifiable facility employees.
Correct by 24 September 2023

There was excessive rusting in the indoor portions of two sheltered enclosures housing 4 raccoons and 2 coatimundis.
The rusting has resulted in holes in the wall with exposed sharp edges and points. This is a risk of injury to the enclosed
animals and also prevents adequate cleaning and sanitization. The rusted areas must be repaired or replaced.
Correct by: 26 September 2023

There was a juvenile mourning dove on display in a glass aquarium in the facility lobby. The only source of ventilation was
a couple of small holes in the wooden top of the enclosure. The bird appeared to have the feathers "fluffed" out, which
can be an indication of discomfort or overheating and can put the bird at risk of respiratory illness or other negative animal
welfare impact. This setup does not provide appropriate ventilation for the enclosed bird and puts the animal at risk. This
is not an appropriate enclosure for any bird, and the dove should be removed from this aquarium and placed in an
appropriate cage as soon as possible.
Corrected at the time of inspection

There was a juvenile mourning dove on display in a glass aquarium in the facility lobby with a light placed on the inside of
the glass shining into the interior of the aquarium. The size of this light in relation to the size of the enclosure is causing an
excessive amount of illumination for the enclosed bird, with no way for the animal to avoid the light if it so desired.
Excessive illumination can be a cause of distress and discomfort to an animal, especially when there is no option to avoid
that light. It can also contribute to excessive heat, especially in a glass enclosure designed to hold heat and humidity. All
birds must have natural or artificial lighting which is of appropriate intensity and duration for the particular species. The
light for this mourning dove is not an appropriate source of illumination and should be changed immediately.
Corrected at the time of inspection

Two ducks were being kept in an enclosure with metal wire flooring. The flooring appeared to be 2x2 or 4x4 wire fence
material. Metal wire is not an appropriate flooring material for aquatic wild birds. There is a high risk of the animals
developing pressure sores from walking on this type of surface. In this enclosure there was no solid surface other than a
wading pool, which means that if the ducks wanted a dry surface the wire was their only option. The ducks should be
removed from this enclosure and placed in an appropriate cage. Metal wire must not be used as flooring for any aquatic
wildlife in the facility.
Corrected at the time of inspection

There was a juvenile mourning dove on display in a glass aquarium in the facility lobby. There was not an appropriate
perch in this enclosure. The bird was sitting on what appeared to be an artificial structure which was much too thick in
diameter to serve as a proper perch. An appropriate perch is one that allows the bird to get off the ground, and is of a
diameter which the bird can fully wrap it's feet around. All birds must be provided with species appropriate perches.
Corrected at the time of inspection
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representative.
n

narrative:
2.131(d)(2) 
   
Handling of animals. 
There was a general lack of readily identifiable attendants throughout the facility. Customers were able to move freely 
through the facility, feeding and interacting with a variety of animals, without appropriate supervision. The facility does not 
utilize public barriers, and relies on employee oversight to ensure proper interactions between visitors and animals. Lack 
of oversight poses a risk both to the animals of the facility, and to visiting personnel as well. All park guests able to 
engage in public contact with the animals must be properly supervised by readily identifiable facility employees. 
Correct by 24 September 2023 
3.125(a) 
   
Facilities, general. 
There was excessive rusting in the indoor portions of two sheltered enclosures housing 4 raccoons and 2 coatimundis. 
The rusting has resulted in holes in the wall with exposed sharp edges and points. This is a risk of injury to the enclosed 
animals and also prevents adequate cleaning and sanitization. The rusted areas must be repaired or replaced.  
Correct by: 26 September 2023 
3.151(b) 
   
Facilities, indoor 
There was a juvenile mourning dove on display in a glass aquarium in the facility lobby. The only source of ventilation was 
a couple of small holes in the wooden top of the enclosure. The bird appeared to have the feathers "fluffed" out, which 
can be an indication of discomfort or overheating and can put the bird at risk of respiratory illness or other negative animal 
welfare impact. This setup does not provide appropriate ventilation for the enclosed bird and puts the animal at risk. This 
is not an appropriate enclosure for any bird, and the dove should be removed from this aquarium and placed in an 
appropriate cage as soon as possible. 
Corrected at the time of inspection 
3.151(c) 
   
Facilities, indoor

There was a juvenile mourning dove on display in a glass aquarium in the facility lobby with a light placed on the inside of 
the glass shining into the interior of the aquarium. The size of this light in relation to the size of the enclosure is causing an 
excessive amount of illumination for the enclosed bird, with no way for the animal to avoid the light if it so desired. 
Excessive illumination can be a cause of distress and discomfort to an animal, especially when there is no option to avoid 
that light. It can also contribute to excessive heat, especially in a glass enclosure designed to hold heat and humidity. All 
birds must have natural or artificial lighting which is of appropriate intensity and duration for the particular species. The 
light for this mourning dove is not an appropriate source of illumination and should be changed immediately. 
Corrected at the time of inspection 
3.153(a)(1)(x) 
   
Primary enclosures. 
Two ducks were being kept in an enclosure with metal wire flooring. The flooring appeared to be 2x2 or 4x4 wire fence 
material. Metal wire is not an appropriate flooring material for aquatic wild birds. There is a high risk of the animals 
developing pressure sores from walking on this type of surface. In this enclosure there was no solid surface other than a 
wading pool, which means that if the ducks wanted a dry surface the wire was their only option. The ducks should be 
removed from this enclosure and placed in an appropriate cage. Metal wire must not be used as flooring for any aquatic 
wildlife in the facility. 
Corrected at the time of inspection 
3.153(a)(2) 
   
Primary enclosures. 
There was a juvenile mourning dove on display in a glass aquarium in the facility lobby. There was not an appropriate 
perch in this enclosure. The bird was sitting on what appeared to be an artificial structure which was much too thick in 
diameter to serve as a proper perch. An appropriate perch is one that allows the bird to get off the ground, and is of a 
diameter which the bird can fully wrap it's feet around. All birds must be provided with species appropriate perches. 
Corrected at the time of inspection 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representative.
